Colin, your explanation of "junk" and "randomness" make sense; thanks for=
 clarifying those.  The idea that a kind of organized set of data that come=
s from outside is useful for another purpose is interesting.  Or it could j=
ust be that the adaptive properties of the brain make it resilient to a ran=
ge of starting conditions, which means that mutations that activate arbitra=
ry bits of "junk" DNA during early organization have no harmful effect, so =
they just tend to accumulate because they don't matter.  Of course, I don't=
 know what the answer is.

ken
